Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Single Beam Ion Sources for Advanced Materials Processing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a single beam ion source that enables the manufacturing of high-quality thin film materials and related products. Thin films have a significant impact on quality of life as they are used widely in semiconductor devices, displays, solar panels, tribological coatings, cell phones, optical filters, and micro-electro-mechanical systems. The annual market of these industry segments exceeds $600 billion and has been steadily increasing. Common methods to produce thin films include physical and chemical vapor depositions, which today have tradeoffs between film quality and manufacturability. A high deposition rate results in loosely packed atoms and subsequently unstable materials properties. Producing high-quality dense films today requires slow deposition at elevated temperatures leading to high manufacturing cost and other limitations, such as inability to use flexible substrates. Ion sources are plasma generation devices that enable ion beams to interact with materials at the atomic level and efficiently produce dense films. The single beam ion sources bring in multiple benefits for thin film fabrication, including superior stability, improved adhesion, low electrical resistivity, high optical transmittance, and smooth surfaces.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will validate the technical and commercial feasibilities of the single beam ion sources particularly suitable for fabricating high-quality thin films and devices. In ion beam assisted thin-film deposition, ions simultaneously interact with the atoms as they are deposited from another source. The ions transfer kinetic energies to the surface atoms so that they can move around to form densely packed films. The single beam ion sources proposed in this project can produce a highly focused beam of ions with tunable energy for optimal processing of the growing films. These unique features are enabled by an innovative design of the electromagnetic fields, which efficiently generate plasmas and extract the ions in a narrow beam. Unlike the conventional racetrack type ion sources, the single beam ion sources can accurately control the ion incident angle, which has strong effects on the surface morphology of the deposited film.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ion sources are plasma generation devices that enable ion beams to interact with materials surfaces at atomic level. Ion beam enhanced thin-film deposition has the potential to produce high-quality films with dense microstructure and superior stability, especially at low temperatures. However, the conventional ion sources such as filament and racetrack types come with their own limitations. Filament type ion sources are vulnerable in reactive gases (e.g. O2) that are detrimental to the filaments. Racetrack type ion sources produce ring-shape beams and require a voltage above 250 V to sustain the plasma discharges, under which the ion energies are subsequently high and can damage the deposited thin films. Therefore, there is a strong need for a plasma source that is compatible with reactive gases and can produce a focused beam of ions with widely tunable energies. 

The goal of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to validate the feasibilities of a single beam ion source that overcomes the limitations of conventional ion sources and is capable of producing high-quality thin films. We have successfully addressed the following objectives to achieve the goal. 

1) Validate the feasibility of single beam ion sources. We started with modeling the electromagnetic fields and plasma discharges of the ion sources. We subsequently designed and engineered the ion sources. We then tested the ion sources to verify the discharge characteristics. Our research successfully validated the feasibility of the single beam ion sources, as evidenced by stable plasma discharges over a wide range of voltage (e.g. 30-250 V) and gas pressure (0.001-0.5 Torr). We also demonstrated a linear single beam ion source that is scalable for large-area coatings.  

2) Clarify the compatibility of the single beam ion sources with other plasma sources. Our initial target applications were ion beam enhanced sputtering deposition of thin films. Therefore, we conducted extensive research to determine the interactions between the single beam ion source and a sputtering magnetron, especially when they operated at different frequencies. We demonstrated stable and compatible discharges of the single beam ion sources with sputtering magnetrons.  

3) Demonstrate the benefits of single beam ion sources. We successfully demonstrated ion source enhanced sputtering deposition of transparent conductive indium-tin-oxide (ITO) thin films. We deposited ITO thin films by sputtering with and without the ion source. Using an optimal ion energy about 100 eV, we successfully produced high-quality polycrystalline ITO films at room temperature. The sheet resistance of the ITO films was reduced by 50% and peak transmittance increased 3%. The significance of these results is that the optimal ion energy is much lower than what a conventional racetrack ion source can supply. We also demonstrated ion source enhanced chemical vapor deposition (CVD) of diamond-like carbon films. The film deposition rates reached ~1.6 mm per hour, which was much higher than conventional CVD. The diamond-like carbon films had a Young?s modulus about 80 GPa, which was better than similar films produced by conventional CVD. 

This project can generate broader impacts to society. Thin films have a significant impact on quality of life as they are used in a wide variety of products, such as semiconductor devices, displays, solar panels, tribological coatings, sensors, optical filters, and micro-electro-mechanical systems. The annual market of these industry segments exceeds $600 billion. The single beam ion sources bring in multiple benefits for thin film fabrication, including high material density, improved adhesion, stable electrical and optical properties, and low surface roughness. Using the single beam ion source to assist sputtering deposition of ITO thin films leads to 50% reduction in sheet resistance and significant saving of this expensive materials. ITO thin films are widely used in displays, solar panels, and automotive defrost applications. The single beam ion source enhanced sputtering addresses a bottleneck in the manufacturing of high-quality ITO films at high rates and low temperatures, greatly reducing the manufacturing costs. The benefits of the ion beam processing apply to many other applications, such as chemical vapor deposition of wear-resistant coatings, exfoliation of graphene, surface cleaning, and reactive sputtering deposition of dense dielectric films.
